G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: NOW COMES THE PLAINTIFF, Jessica Collins, in the above-entitled matter, and hereby requests that this Honorable Court modify the current custody order concerning the minor child, Samantha Collins, pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and other applicable laws.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 1.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 209C, § 1, and G.L. c. 208, § 28.

General Laws c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31.proposition: General Laws c. 208, §§ 28, 31 (governing modification of custody orders and the best interests of the child standard).

General Laws c. 209C, \u00a7 10.proposition: General Laws c. 209C, § 10 (jurisdiction to modify custody orders).

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Massachusetts law holds that the best interests of the child are the paramount concern in custody determinations. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985).
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely interprets G.L. c. 208, § 30 by stating that “upon cause shown” means removal must be in the best interests of the child and then emphasizes that the best interests of the children are the paramount concern in the analysis. Although the case is about removal rather than an initial custody award, the court’s discussion is expressly framed in terms of custody/removal determinations under the divorce statute and makes clear that the governing standard is the child’s best interests. Thus it validly supports the cited proposition about Massachusetts law’s focus on the child’s best interests in custody determinations.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that … the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (200.proposition: The safety, stability, and welfare of the child are central to this Court’s review. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (2003).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (200.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames custody determinations around the child’s welfare, repeatedly emphasizing that the ‘best interests of the child’ and the child’s welfare are the paramount concern, and that stability itself is of enormous benefit to the child. The court’s analysis centers on factors like continuity, stability, and the child’s needs in reviewing the custody order. This directly supports the proposition that the safety, stability, and welfare of the child are central to the court’s review.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (200.relevant_excerpt: In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is “best for the child” is firmly rooted in American history… The “best interests” standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… and has been adhered to ever since… It cautions against rearranging a child’s living arrangements… when it is generally wiser and safer not to meddle in arrangements that are already serving the child’s needs. If the parenting arrangement… is satisfactory… it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement… Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child…

Familias Unidas por la Educaci\u00f3n v..raw_text: Familias Unidas por la Educación v. Bresnahan, 501 Mass. 839 (2020)
Familias Unidas por la Educaci\u00f3n v..proposition: This request is not meant to penalize the Defendant due to his medical condition but rather to protect the well-being of the child in accordance with the principles set forth in Familias Unidas por la Educación v. Bresnahan, 501 Mass. 839 (2020).

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996) (material change in circumstances standard for custody modification).
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly identifies and applies the statutory and common-law standard that a custody order may be modified only upon a finding of a material and substantial change in circumstances and that the modification must be in the child’s best interests. The court quotes G.L. c. 208, § 28, cites prior cases, and then analyzes whether the mother’s post-divorce rehabilitation constitutes such a material and substantial change. Thus, it is proper authority for the material-change-in-circumstances standard in custody modification cases.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: "General Laws c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, enables a Probate Court judge, upon finding that ‘a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred’ to modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody arrangements of minor children, where the modification ‘is necessary in the best interests of the children.’ See Hartog v. Hartog, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 124, 128 (1989), and cases cited. ‘In determining whether there has been a material change in the parties’ circumstances, the probate judge must weigh the relevant circumstances; the resolution of the various factors rests within the judge’s sound discretion.’"}

Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.proposition: Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998) (parent’s ability to meet the child’s needs as a central factor).
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.support_reasoning: The case is primarily about SSDI dependency benefits as a credit toward child support, plus issues of attachment and custody modification. While it recites the statutory standard that custody and support orders must be consistent with the best interests of the child, it does not identify or discuss a parent’s ability to meet the child’s needs as a ‘central factor’ in that analysis. The opinion contains no focused treatment or holding elevating that consideration above other best‑interest factors, so it does not support the specific proposition cited.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding ‘that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].’ The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge.”

Pearson v. Pearson, 52 Mass. App. Ct. 15.raw_text: Pearson v. Pearson, 52 Mass. App. Ct. 156 (2001)
Pearson v. Pearson, 52 Mass. App. Ct. 15.proposition: Pearson v. Pearson, 52 Mass. App. Ct. 156 (2001) (parent’s health and capacity to provide adequate care as grounds for modification).
Pearson v. Pearson, 52 Mass. App. Ct. 15.support_reasoning: The opinion in Pearson v. Pearson is a child-support and attorney’s-fees modification case focused on income levels, guidelines, and educational/medical expense allocations. It does not discuss modification of custody or support based on a parent’s health or capacity to provide adequate care. While the mother mentions the children’s emotional problems and her decision to work less, the court’s analysis concerns earning capacity and financial resources, not parental health or caregiving ability as a ground for modification. Thus, it does not support the cited proposition.
Pearson v. Pearson, 52 Mass. App. Ct. 15.relevant_excerpt: “Although she sold her house at a $300,000 profit, she lost $50,000 in one ill-advised investment and reduced her work hours to spend more time with the children, both of whom had developed emotional problems… Even so, the former wife contends that the judge wrongly attributed income to her for work that she voluntarily eschewed to attend to her emotionally troubled children… Our cases hold otherwise… (discussing principle that earning capacity of parent rather than actual income may be considered in determining child support orders).”

D.L. v. G.L., 61 Mass. App. Ct. 488 (200.raw_text: D.L. v. G.L., 61 Mass. App. Ct. 488 (2004)
D.L. v. G.L., 61 Mass. App. Ct. 488 (200.proposition: D.L. v. G.L., 61 Mass. App. Ct. 488 (2004) (necessity to protect the child emotionally and physically).
D.L. v. G.L., 61 Mass. App. Ct. 488 (200.support_reasoning: The opinion is a detailed equitable-distribution and support decision focused on classification and division of trust interests, alimony, and tax effects in a divorce. It does not discuss standards for custody, visitation, or any doctrine framed as taking actions for the necessity of protecting a child emotionally or physically. The only references to the child concern financial support (child support and tuition), not protective or welfare-based custody principles, so it does not support the cited proposition.
D.L. v. G.L., 61 Mass. App. Ct. 488 (200.relevant_excerpt: “Child support in the amount of $800 per week, exclusive of the child’s private school tuition and educational costs, which the husband was to pay from funds held in a trust for the child, was also ordered.”

M.R. v. G.P., 58 Mass. App. Ct. 1111 (20.raw_text: M.R. v. G.P., 58 Mass. App. Ct. 1111 (2003)
M.R. v. G.P., 58 Mass. App. Ct. 1111 (20.proposition: M.R. v. G.P., 58 Mass. App. Ct. 1111 (2003) (limitations on custodial abilities due to medical condition warrant modification).
